author: wjmelements
content: In about half of the EXCHANGE uses it replaces 3 bytes with 2. In one case it replaces 4 bytes and the others replace 6. The 3 to 2 will probably be the most common.

author: frangio_
content: those are sort of "micro" improvements at the level of each instruction. i was thinking what the total impact would be in a real-world contract. i don't think it scales up linearly, it might be a lot less impactful at that level. for example, if you have to rearrange O(n) stack positions, my napkin analysis is that doing it with EXCHANGE instructions versus a series of SWAPs would only result in O(1) fewer instructions (0 to 2)

author: wjmelements
content: doesnâ€™t sound like a real world contract to me
